Closer examination - it looks as if this photo is earlier than the Bayliss one, comparing the vegetation on the wedge of embankment.  

Opinions?

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Any chance of working out the number on the locomotive? My computer tends to digitise at the magnification needed. Can State Records help?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] "Class Z1412 (G23) No.34 locomotive" is on the subtitle (which are renowned to be inaccurate).  Does that help?  it looks like an old loco to me, but I know zilch about trains.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Thanks! Trust me not to read the obvious! 

The Great Zig Zag was opened on 18 October 1869 and the (G) 23 class, of which 34 was the twelfth member, entered service between September and October 1865. Thirteen were in service by December 1870 which would certainly date the picture from the earliest of days of this engineering marvel. This makes sense, as the final four of this class were fitted with 168 cm coupled wheels which made the handling of steeper grades - such as would be encountered on the Zig Zag the Blue Mountains, and the line around Picton - easier. The original nine of the class had 175 cm coupled wheels and reduced tractive effort.

One could conjecture, therefore, that the shot was taken during locomotive trials - hence the person at the rear of the train and the person looking up the line (although the same photograph in William a Bayley's book 'Lithgow  Zig Zag Railway'  [undated] describes the train as a "tourist train"). Either explanation is plausible.

The story of the (G) 23 class is an interesting one. Although they entered service as a 2-4-0 locomotive between 1865 and 1870, from 1890s they were transshipped from the workshops rebuilt as a 4-4-0 locomotive which completely altered their appearance!. They were then transferred to the south-western and far-western depots where there were few grades. 

The last remaining member of the class (Z1405 - under the 1924 reclassification) was scrapped in June 1952 having travelled 1 866 880 km. Sadly none of the class remain 

(I'm grateful to Leon Oberg's book Locomotives of Australia for some additional information about the (G) 23 class.)

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: I have now posted to my photostream pictures of both versions of the (G) 23 - (or Z14) class. Both pictures from NSW State Records.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I just found a John Degotardi (Snr) photo of the same view very slightly to the right, dated 1869-70. Remarkable lack of vegetation on the scree slopes compared with this photo, which implies this is several years later.
